facts.text: Prospecting license granted on 26-3-1915 to Messrs Bird and Co. by Court of Wards representing Ramgarh Estate.

anchor.surface_text: a prospecting license granted on 26-3-1915 in favour of Messrs Bird and Co., by the Court of Wards as representing the Ram- garh Estate and of two deeds dated 23-11-1917 and 1-6-1937 executed by the Court of Wards modifying the terms of the license dated 26-3-1915.

facts.text: Ramgarh Raj is an ancient principality in Bihar with three coal-fields: Bokaro Jharia, Bokaro Ramgarh and Karanpura.

anchor.surface_text: The Ramgarh Raj is an ancient principality situate in Bihar. It has three companyl-fields, Bokaro Jharia, Bokaro Ramgarh and Karanpura. Of these, the Karanpura companyl-fields are the largest being of the extent of 550 sq. miles, of which about 415 sq. miles belonged to the estate.

facts.text: Karanpura coal-fields extent 550 sq. miles, about 415 sq. miles belonged to the estate.

anchor.surface_text: Of these, the Karanpura companyl-fields are the largest being of the extent of 550 sq. miles, of which about 415 sq. miles belonged to the estate.

facts.text: On 26-11-1907 Raja Ramnarain Singh granted prospecting license for Bokaro Ramgarh coal-fields to Messrs Anderson Wright Co.

anchor.surface_text: On 26-11-1907 Raja Ram narain Singh, the proprietor of the estate, granted in favour of Messrs Anderson Wright Co., a prospecting license in respect of the Bokaro Ramgarh companyl-fields, referred to in these proceeding as the Bokaro license.

facts.text: Raja Ramnarain Singh died on 26-1-1913 leaving widow Rikinath Kaur and minor son Lakshminarain Singh.

anchor.surface_text: but before anything was companycluded, he died on 26-1-1913 leaving him surviving his widow, Rikinath Kaur, and a minor son, Lakshminarain Singh.

facts.text: At time of Raja Ramnarain Singh's death, estate debts amounted to about Rs. 9 lakhs.

anchor.surface_text: At the time of his death, the debts owing by the estate amounted to about Rs. 9 lakhs.

facts.text: Court of Wards took over management of estate on 20-5-1913.

anchor.surface_text: On 20-5-1913 the Court of Wards took over the management of the estate,

facts.text: Prospecting license deed executed on 26-3-1915 for six years, salami Rs. 1,00,000, minimum ground rent Rs. 8,000 per annum from second year.

anchor.surface_text: and eventually on 29-7-1914 the terms were finally agreed upon, and on 26-3-1915 the deed of prospecting license was actually executed. Its main terms were as follows It was to be in force for a period of six years. A sum of Rs. 1,00,000 was paid as salami. The licensees were to pay a minimum ground rent of Rs. 8,000 per annum companymencing from the second year of the license,

facts.text: Messrs Bird and Co. advanced Rs. 9 lakhs as loan to estate without interest, to be adjusted against royalties.

anchor.surface_text: As companysideration for the grant of the license, Messrs Bird and Co., were to advance Rs. 9 lakhs as loan to the estate. This amount was number to carry interest and was to be discharged by adjusting the royalties which would become payable under the leases.

facts.text: Deed dated 23-11-1917 modified terms of 1915 license, extending period to 12 years, further extensions conditional on leases taken.

anchor.surface_text: Ultimately, on 23- 11-1917 the manager of the Court of Wards executed a deed modifying the terms of the deed dated 26-3-1915. Under this deed, the period of license was extended in the first instance from 6 to 12 years that is to say, it would expire on 26-3-1927 instead of on 26-3-1921 as originally fixed.

facts.text: Raja Lakshminarain Singh became major on 6-4-1919 and died on 10-4-1919 leaving minor son Raja Kamakshya Narain Singh.

anchor.surface_text: Raja Lakshminarain Singh, the ward, became a major on 6-4- 1919, and died shortly thereafter on 10-4-1919 leaving him surviving a minor son, Raja Kamakshya Narain Singh, the main respondent in these appeals.

facts.text: Court of Wards continued management until Raja Kamakshya Narain Singh became major on 10-8-1937.

anchor.surface_text: The Court of Wards accordingly companytinued in management of the estate on behalf of the Raja until 10-8-1937, when he became a major.

facts.text: Appellant Company registered on 14-7-1920 and took over interests of Messrs Bird and Co. under 1915 license as modified.

anchor.surface_text: On 14-7-1920, the appellant Company was registered under the provisions of the Indian Companies Act, and it took over the interests of Messrs Bird Co., under the license dated 26-3-1915 as modified by the deed of variation dated 23-11-1917.

facts.text: Company took six leases covering 17,539 bighas between 17-7-1922 and 17-7-1933.

anchor.surface_text: In pursuance of these deeds, the Company took six leases companyering in all an area of 17,539 bighas on divers dates between 17-7-1922 and 17-7-1933.

facts.text: Three additional leases obtained on 2-8-1937 covering 2,461 bighas to make up 20,000 bighas.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, it applied for and obtained three leases on 2-8-1937 companyering an area of 2,461 bighas, thus making up along with the six leases mentioned above, the minimum area of 20,000 bighas.

facts.text: Deed dated 1-6-1937 modified clause 6 of 1917 deed regarding minimum royalty payment.

anchor.surface_text: and on 1-6-1937 a deed was executed providing in modification of clause 6, as it stood in the deed dated 23-11-1917, that the minimum royalty for the areas in excess of 10,000 bighas was number to become payable by the companypany until railway facilities for transport of the companyl from the mouth of the pit were available or from 26-3-1951, whichever happened earlier.

facts.text: Raja sent notice on 9-3-1939 repudiating 1915 license and 1917, 1937 deeds.

anchor.surface_text: On 9-3-1939 he sent a numberice to the appellant repudiating the license dated 26-3- 1915 and the two deeds of variation dated 23-11-1917 and 1-6-1937 as number binding on him.

facts.text: Appellant instituted Title Suit No. 28 of 1940 on 8-6-1940 for specific performance.

anchor.surface_text: followed it up by instituting on 8-6-1940 Title Suit No. 28 of 1940 in the companyrt of the Subordinate Judge of Hazaribagh for companypelling specific performance thereof.

facts.text: Raja filed Title Suit No. 82 of 1940 on 9-8-1940 seeking declaration deeds void.

anchor.surface_text: On 9-8-1940 the Raja filed Title Suit No. 82 of 1940 in the Sub-Court, Hazaribagh, and therein, he pleaded that the deed dated 26-3-1915 was void,

facts.text: Subordinate Judge on 30-4-1943 held 1915 and 1917 deeds valid, 1937 invalid.

anchor.surface_text: by his judgment dated 30-4-1943 he held that the deeds dated 26-3-1915 and 23-11-1917 were intra vires the powers of the Court of Wards, that they were beneficial to the estate, and were therefore valid,

facts.text: Patna High Court on 27-10-1949 held all three deeds invalid.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Atul Chandra Gupta, learned counsel for the Raja, has limited his attack on the deed dated 26-3-1915 to the ground that it was not for the benefit of the ward, because the clause therein relating to the payment of cess, or more compendiously, the cess clause was less advantageous to him than the corresponding clause in the Bokaro license, and the Court of Wards executed the deed in question without bestowing any thought to it.

issues.text: Whether the Court of Wards had no power to enter into the transaction in the deed dated 23-11-1917 which had the effect of preventing the ward from dealing with his estate for over 32 years after majority and binding him to grant leases to 1951 at 1915 rates?

holdings.text: The exercise of power under section 18 of the Bengal Court of Wards Act is conditioned on the subjective judgment of the Court of Wards that the act is for the benefit of the property and advantage of the ward, not on objective benefit in fact.

anchor.surface_text: Now, what is the true scope of section 18? Is the exercise of the power conferred by that section conditioned on the act being in fact for the benefit of the ward, or is it sufficient that the Court of Wards judges it to be for the benefit of the property and the advantage of the ward? The statute confides in clear and unambiguous terms the authority to judge whether the act is beneficial to the estate, to the Court of Wards and not to any outside authority.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of 'as it may judge' imports subjective satisfaction; distinguishes objective tests; relies on Liversidge v. Anderson and Allcroft precedents.

holdings.text: Exercise of power under s.18 can be impugned only for lack of bona fides (fraud on power) or non-application of mind; not for error on merits if honest judgment reached.

anchor.surface_text: That being the true scope of the power conferred by section 18, what are the grounds on which the exercise of such a power could be impugned in a court of law? It can be attacked on the ground that the Court of Wards did not act bona fide and in the interests of the ward, and that its action amounted to a fraud on the power. It can also be attacked on the ground that the Court of Wards did not, in fact, apply its mind...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows principles from Allcroft v. Bishop of London; honest judgment not reviewable on merits unless no real consideration.

holdings.text: Deed dated 26-3-1915 is valid; Court of Wards applied mind to cess clause after scrutiny and approval.

anchor.surface_text: As we have held that the Court of Wards did apply its mind to the question and formed its own judgment on it, its decision is not open to question, and the attack on the deed dated 26-3-1915 must in consequence fail.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence of discussions, alterations by officers, approval by legal adviser and Board shows application of mind; subjective judgment protected.

holdings.text: Court of Wards had power under s.18 to enter deed dated 23-11-1917 despite extending license beyond ward's majority to 1951 at 1915 rates.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the deed of 1917 cannot be held to be incompetent on any of the grounds put forward by the respondent.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.18 unqualified; no statutory tie to minority; distinguishes Guardians Act; prudent management till end of charge.

holdings.text: In granting deed dated 23-11-1917, Court of Wards considered benefit to ward/estate, not just licensees.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, we must hold that the deed is not open to attack on the ground that in entering into the transaction, the Court of Wards did not consider the interests of the ward.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Correspondence evidences consideration of long-term exploitation, minimum rents, avoiding abandonment for estate benefit.

holdings.text: Deed dated 23-11-1917 validly sanctioned under s.18 by Board letters dated 3-7-1916 and 9-10-1917 covering essential terms.

anchor.surface_text: We have no hesitation in holding that the Board directed by its letter dated 9-10-1917 the execution of the agreement dated 23-11-1917, and that it was validly executed under section 18.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prior sanction to essentials sufficient per Gulabsingh and Ramkanai precedents; Rule 242 inapplicable to agreements.

holdings.text: Deed dated 1-6-1937 not binding on estate.

anchor.surface_text: Thus, the appellant does not challenge the correctness of the decision of the courts below that the deed dated 1-6-1937 is not binding on the estate.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellant accepts lower courts' finding; no challenge.

holdings.text: Leases dated 2-8-1937 valid despite invalid clause from 1-6-1937 deed; invalid clause severable.

anchor.surface_text: The contention therefore that the lease deeds dated 2-8-1937 are inoperative must be rejected.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Unauthorized clause severable if not integral; leases advantageous without it; sanction to transaction precedes merits.

precedents.citation: Nakkuda Ali v-. M. F. De. S. Jayaratne 1

anchor.surface_text: Nakkuda Ali v-. M. F. De. S. Jayaratne 1 . There, the Board was companysidering the meaning of the words where the Controller has reasonable grounds to believe occurring in a Regulation of Ceylon.

precedents.case_name: Nakkuda Ali v M F De S Jayaratne
precedents.cited_proposition: Interpretation of words 'where the Controller has reasonable grounds to believe' requires objective reasonable grounds, not mere subjective satisfaction

anchor.surface_text: Liversidge v.Sir John Anderson 2  was relied on as establishing that position.

precedents.cited_proposition: Words like 'if A has X' import objective standard, not subjective 'if A thinks he has X'
precedents.cited_holding: Regulation 18B words 'reasonable cause to believe' mean objective reasonable cause

anchor.surface_text: In Liversidge v. Sir John Anderson 1 , Lord Atkin who held that the words of Regulation 18-B of the Defence Regulations 1939 that if the Secretary of State has reasonable cause to believe meant if, in fact, there was reasonable cause for the belief,

precedents.cited_proposition: Words importing objective standard like 'reasonable cause' are positive facts determinable by third party

precedents.citation: Allcroft v. Lord Bishop of London Lighton v. Lord Bishop of London 1

anchor.surface_text: Allcroft v. Lord Bishop of London Lighton v. Lord Bishop of London 1 . There, the statute provided for certain action being taken unless the Bishop shall be of opinion that proceedings shall number be taken.

precedents.case_name: Allcroft v Lord Bishop of London
precedents.cited_proposition: Court cannot review honest exercise of discretionary judgment even if erroneous or incomplete consideration
precedents.cited_holding: Bishop's honest opinion not reviewable on merits

anchor.surface_text: Ashutosh Dhar v. Amir Mollah 1  and Mahanand Sahai v. Mussmat Sayedunissa Bibi 2  in support of this position.

precedents.case_name: Mahanand Sahai v Mussmat Sayedunissa Bibi
precedents.cited_proposition: Parties can contract out of statutory rights under Cess Act

precedents.citation: Mahanand Sahai v. Mussmat Sayedunissa Bibi 1

anchor.surface_text: Mahanand Sahai v. Mussmat Sayedunissa Bibi  1  It is indisputable that when an exemption is claimed from statutory liability, the companytract under which exemption is claimed, must be strictly companystrued against the claimant

precedents.case_name: Mahanand Sahai v Mussmat Sayedunissa Bibi
precedents.cited_proposition: Contract exempting from statutory liability must be strictly construed; must clearly intend to vary statute
precedents.cited_holding: No contract contrary spelled from general payment clause

anchor.surface_text: Gulabsingh v. Seth Gokuldas 1  was relied on in support of this position. There, the Deputy Commissioner had sent to the Commissioner a proposal to borrow Rs. 1,00,000 from the plaintiffs firm,

precedents.cited_proposition: Sanction under s18 need not be to precise terms of document; general sanction to transaction sufficient if essentials approved
precedents.cited_holding: No need for sanction to actual mortgage document if general sanction to borrow given

precedents.citation: Ramkanai Singh Deb Darpashaha v. Mathewson 2

anchor.surface_text: In Ramkanai Singh Deb Darpashaha v. Mathewson  2  the Commissioner had sanctioned a patni lease, but the lease deed which was actually executed had number been submitted to his approval.

precedents.case_name: Ramkanai Singh Deb Darpashaha v Mathewson
precedents.cited_proposition: Sanction to transaction in essential particulars sufficient even if final deed not submitted
precedents.cited_holding: Challenge on ground final document not sanctioned cannot succeed if essentials sanctioned

anchor.surface_text: Ramkanai Singh Deb Darpashaha v. Mathewson 2  that the document as finally drafted had number been submitted again for its appro-  1  1913 L.R. 40 I.A. 117.

precedents.case_name: Ramkanai Singh Deb Darpashaha v Mathewson
precedents.cited_proposition: Final document need not be resubmitted if essentials sanctioned

anchor.surface_text: Now, what is the true scope of section 18? Is the exercise of the power conferred by that section conditioned on the act being in fact for the benefit of the ward, or is it sufficient that the Court of Wards judges it to be for the benefit of the property and the advantage of the ward? The statute confides in clear and unambiguous terms the authority to judge whether the act is beneficial to the estate, to the Court of Wards and not to any outside authority.
The appeals must accordingly be allowed, the decrees of the companypanyrt below set aside, and these of the trial companypanyrt restored.

anchor.surface_text: That being the true scope of the power conferred by section 18, what are the grounds on which the exercise of such a power could be impugned in a court of law? It can be attacked on the ground that the Court of Wards did not act bona fide and in the interests of the ward, and that its action amounted to a fraud on the power. It can also be attacked on the ground that the Court of Wards did not, in fact, apply its mind...
